text:

Take a step down Taiwan’s Rainbow Village – a town saved by a grandfather who created exquisite street art to stop the military taking over his home. Close Fireworks in Taiwan Celebrate Chinese New Year UP NEXT VIDEO Fireworks in Taiwan Celebrate Chinese New Year 
In the late 1940s, when Chiang Kai Shek and his Chinese Nationalist Party retreated to Taiwan as the People’s Republic of China came into being, he was followed by over two million people, including soldiers from the Republic of China’s (ROC) armed forces – and their families. Taiwan’s Rainbow Village was saved by a grandfather who created exquisite street art to stop the military taking over his home. Source: Chris Ashton 
The government set up ‘temporary’ “Military Dependents’ Villages” to house all these people – quickly assembled, shoddy housing not meant to last. But they did. 
Over the years many were abandoned, and some became slums for an aging population. In the early 90s the government planned to demolish these villages, replacing them with high rise apartments. Source: Chris Ahston Grandpa Huang, a veteran who lived in Taichung, wasn’t about to lose his home. Source: Chris Ashton 
In the early 90s the government started an aggressive program of demolishing these villages, replacing them with high rise apartments, but (then) 87-year old Grandpa Huang, a veteran who lived in the Taichung village, wasn’t about to lose his home. 
He started to paint. He painted colourful murals all over his home, the gates, walls, walkways, even the pavement. 
The self-taught artist used bright colours and painted very random and imaginative figures including plants, animals, monsters, celebrities and traditional cultural heroes. Grandpa Huang started to paint. He painted colourful murals all over his home. Source: Chris Ashton He then began to paint the gates, walls, walkways, even the pavement. Source: Chris Ashton 
The students at nearby Ling Tung University took photos of his progress and spread them around online – and they went viral before ‘viral’ was actually a thing. 
This newly dubbed “Rainbow Village” soon became a tourist attraction as people from all over started to visit him while he painted. This newly dubbed “Rainbow Village” soon became a tourist attraction as people from all over. Source: Chris Ashton Tourists offered donations and supported the Grandpa Huang. Source: Chris Ashton 
These tourists offered donations and supported the aging grandfather, who was born in Hong Kong and fought against the communists in the ROC Army. 
Grandpa Huang’s peaceful protest gained enough sympathy from his countrymen to convince the government to let him stay. This has to be one of the most breathtaking and peaceful protests. Source: Chris Ashton 
If you’re visiting Taichung, it’s worth visiting Rainbow Village (if only for a selfie opportunity), but remember, the life of a retired soldier isn’t one of great wealth, so make sure you make a donation to Grandpa Huang’s retirement fund – buy a handmade souvenir or a postcard. 
The Rainbow Grandfather is still going strong as he approaches his centenary, and he’s always happy to pose for a photo with you. Close Timelapse Shows World's Largest Street Art Mural in Rio De Janeiro UP NEXT VIDEO
